content:
It's always a good idea to confirm the meeting details in the email, especially when sharing files in advance. This helps ensure that both you and the potential client are on the same page regarding the meeting logistics.

By confirming the meeting details, you can:

1. Avoid misunderstandings: Double-check that the potential client has the correct date, time, and any other important details.
2. Set clear expectations: Reiterate the purpose of the meeting and what you hope to discuss.
3. Show professionalism: Demonstrate your attention to detail and commitment to being organized.

Here's an updated email example:

"Hi [Potential Client],

I've shared a folder containing the necessary files for our meeting on Tuesday at 2:00 pm. You can access the folder via this link: [insert link]. Please take a few minutes to review the materials before our call.

As a reminder, our meeting is scheduled for:

* Date: Tuesday
* Time: 2:00 pm
* Duration: approximately 60 minutes

I'm looking forward to discussing the project with you on Tuesday. If you have any questions or concerns, feel free to reach out to me.

Best,
[Your Name]"

By including the meeting details, you'll ensure that both parties are aligned and prepared for the meeting.
